class kazu.data.data.CuratedTerm[source]#

Bases: object

A CuratedTerm is a means to modify the behaviour of a specific SynonymTerm.

This can affect both the behaviour of kazu.modelling.ontology_preprocessing.base.OntologyParser, and dictionary based NER (if using the kazu.steps.joint_ner_and_linking.explosion.ExplosionStringMatchingStep). This is controlled by the list of SynonymTermActions attached.

Example 1:

The string ‘ALL’ is highly ambiguous. It might mean several diseases, or simply ‘all’. Therefore, we want to add a curation as follows, so that it will only be used as a linking target and not for dictionary based NER:

CuratedTerm(
    curated_synonym="ALL",
    case_sensitive=True,
    actions=(
        SynonymTermAction(
            behaviour=SynonymTermBehaviour.ADD_FOR_LINKING_ONLY,
            associated_id_sets=frozenset((EquivalentIdSet(("my_id", "my_source")),)),
        ),
    ),
    mention_confidence=MentionConfidence.POSSIBLE,
)

Example 2:

The string ‘LH’ is incorrectly identified as a synonym of the PLOD1 (ENSG00000083444) gene, whereas more often than not, it’s actually an abbreviation of Lutenising Hormone. We therefore want to drop this reference, and add a new one to LHB (ENSG00000104826, or Lutenising Hormone Subunit Beta)

The CuratedTerm we therefore want is:

CuratedTerm(
    curated_synonym="LH",
    case_sensitive=True,
    actions=(
        SynonymTermAction(behaviour=SynonymTermBehaviour.DROP_SYNONYM_TERM_FOR_LINKING),
        SynonymTermAction(
            behaviour=SynonymTermBehaviour.ADD_FOR_LINKING_ONLY,
            associated_id_sets=frozenset(
                (EquivalentIdSet(("ENSG00000104826", "ENSEMBL")),)
            ),
        ),
    ),
    mention_confidence=MentionConfidence.POSSIBLE,
)

Example 3:

A SynonymTerm has an unwanted EquivalentIdSet attached to it, but is otherwise good. We want to remove this set. First, we drop the original term, then add a new one with only the target ids

CuratedTerm(
    curated_synonym="LH",
    case_sensitive=True,
    actions=(
        SynonymTermAction(behaviour=SynonymTermBehaviour.DROP_SYNONYM_TERM_FOR_LINKING),
        SynonymTermAction(
            behaviour=SynonymTermBehaviour.ADD_FOR_LINKING_ONLY,
            associated_id_sets=frozenset(
                (EquivalentIdSet(("my good id", "my source")),)
            ),
        ),
    ),
    mention_confidence=MentionConfidence.POSSIBLE,
)

Example 4:

A SynonymTerm has an alternative synonym not referenced in the underlying ontology, and we want to add it. We want it to inherit all the behaviour from the original term

CuratedTerm(
    curated_synonym="breast carcinoma",
    case_sensitive=True,
    source_term="breast cancer",
    actions=(
        SynonymTermAction(behaviour=SynonymTermBehaviour.INHERIT_FROM_SOURCE_TERM),
    ),
    mention_confidence=MentionConfidence.POSSIBLE,
)

Notes:

mention_confidence is currently non-functional, and will be expanded upon at a later date

source_term: str | None = None#

The original term that is used as a ‘seed’ term for this curation. note, this is used for NER to determine how linking is performed. If you also want to use this curation as a linking target for non-dictionary based NER processes, or the term is identical to the one used in the source ontology, this should be set to None, so that a novel term_norm is calculated

class kazu.data.data.Entity[source]#

Bases: object

A kazu.data.data.Entity is a container for information about a single entity detected within a kazu.data.data.Section

Within an kazu.data.data.Entity, the most important fields are Entity.match (the actual string detected), Entity.syn_term_to_synonym_terms, a dict of kazu.data.data.SynonymTermWithMetrics (candidates for knowledgebase hits) and Entity.mappings, the final product of linked references to the underlying entity

__init__(match, entity_class, spans, namespace, mention_confidence=MentionConfidence.HIGHLY_LIKELY, mappings=<factory>, metadata=<factory>, syn_term_to_synonym_terms=<factory>)[source]#

is_completely_overlapped(other)[source]#

True if all CharSpan instances are completely encompassed by all other CharSpan instances

Parameters:

other –

Returns:

is_partially_overlapped(other)[source]#

True if only one CharSpan instance is defined in both self and other, and they are partially overlapped

If multiple CharSpan are defined in both self and other, this becomes pathological, as while they may overlap in the technical sense, they may have distinct semantic meaning. For instance, consider the case where we may want to use is_partially_overlapped to select the longest annotation span suggested by some NER system.

case 1: text: the patient has metastatic liver cancers entity1: metastatic liver cancer -> [CharSpan(16,39] entity2: liver cancers -> [CharSpan(27,40]

result: is_partially_overlapped -> True (entities are part of same concept)

case 2: non-contiguous entities

text: lung and liver cancer lung cancer -> [CharSpan(0,4), CharSpan(1521 liver cancer -> [CharSpan(9,21)]

result: is_partially_overlapped -> False (entities are distinct)

Parameters:

other –

Returns:

class kazu.data.data.ParserAction[source]#

Bases: object

A ParserAction changes the behaviour of a kazu.modelling.ontology_preprocessing.base.OntologyParser in a global sense.

A ParserAction overrides any default behaviour of the parser, and also any conflicts that may occur with SynonymTermActions.

These actions are useful for eliminating unwanted behaviour. For example, the root of the Mondo ontology is http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_0000001, which has a default label of ‘All’. Since this is such a common word, and not very useful in terms of linking, we might want a global action so that this ID is not used anywhere in a Kazu pipeline.

The parser_to_target_id_mappings field should specify the parser name and an affected IDs if required. See ParserBehaviour for the type of actions that are possible.

__init__(behaviour, parser_to_target_id_mappings=<factory>)[source]#
Parameters:

  • behaviour (ParserBehaviour) –

  • parser_to_target_id_mappings (Dict[str, Set[str]]) –

Return type:

class kazu.data.data.SynonymTerm[source]#

Bases: object

a SynonymTerm is a container for a single normalised synonym, and is produced by an OntologyParser implementation. It may be composed of multiple terms that normalise to the same unique string (e.g. “breast cancer” and “Breast Cancer”). The number of associated_id_sets that this synonym maps to is determined by the score_and_group_ids method of the associated OntologyParser

__init__(terms, term_norm, parser_name, is_symbolic, associated_id_sets, mapping_types, aggregated_by, original_term=None)[source]#
Parameters:

  • mapping_types (FrozenSet[str]) –

  • aggregated_by (EquivalentIdAggregationStrategy) –

  • original_term (str | None) –

Return type:

class kazu.data.data.SynonymTermAction[source]#

Bases: object

A SynonymTermAction is an action that affects the SynonymTerms that a parser produces.

See SynonymTermBehaviour for the type of actions that are possible.

associated_id_sets: FrozenSet[EquivalentIdSet] | None = None#

If specified, will override the parser defaults for the associated SynonymTerm, as long as conflicts do not occur

behaviour: SynonymTermBehaviour#
class kazu.data.data.SynonymTermBehaviour[source]#

Bases: AutoNameEnum

An enumeration.

ADD_FOR_LINKING_ONLY = 'ADD_FOR_LINKING_ONLY'#

use the term only as a linking target. Note, this is not required if the term is already in the underlying ontology, as all ontology terms are included as linking targets by default (Also see DROP_SYNONYM_TERM_FOR_LINKING)

ADD_FOR_NER_AND_LINKING = 'ADD_FOR_NER_AND_LINKING'#

use the term for both dictionary based NER and as a linking target.

DROP_SYNONYM_TERM_FOR_LINKING = 'DROP_SYNONYM_TERM_FOR_LINKING'#

do not use this term as a linking target. Normally, you would use this for a term you want to remove from the underlying ontology (e.g. a ‘bad’ synonym). If the term does not exist, has no effect

IGNORE = 'IGNORE'#

do nothing. Useful if you want to catalogue a term as “I’ve looked at this but don’t want to use it for NER”

INHERIT_FROM_SOURCE_TERM = 'INHERIT_FROM_SOURCE_TERM'#

used if the containing Curation has source_term !=None, in which case all behaviours are inherited

class kazu.data.data.SynonymTermWithMetrics[source]#

Bases: SynonymTerm

Similar to SynonymTerm, but also allows metrics to be scored. As these metrics are not used in the hash function, care should be taken when hashing of this object is required
